questions.text: What is an array?
questions.solution: An array is a data structure, a collection of items stored at contiguous memory locations, typically of the same data type.

questions.text: Which operation takes O(1) time in an array?
questions.option2: Inserting an element at the beginning
questions.option4: Deleting an element from the middle
questions.solution: Accessing an element by its index in an array takes constant time, O(1), because the memory address can be directly calculated.

questions.text: What is the primary disadvantage of static arrays?
questions.solution: The primary disadvantage of static arrays is their fixed size, meaning their capacity cannot be changed after declaration.

questions.text: What is a linked list?
questions.option1: A sequence of elements in contiguous memory
questions.option2: A collection of nodes where each node points to the next
questions.solution: A linked list is a linear data structure where elements are not stored at contiguous memory locations. Instead, each element (node) stores a reference to the next element.

questions.text: Which operation is most efficient in a singly linked list?
questions.option4: Inserting at the end (without tail pointer)
questions.solution: Inserting at the beginning of a singly linked list is efficient (O(1)) as it only requires updating the head pointer.

questions.text: What does a 'null' pointer signify in a linked list?
questions.solution: A null pointer in the 'next' field of a node signifies the end of the linked list.

questions.text: What is a 'process' in an operating system?
questions.solution: A process is an instance of a computer program that is being executed. It includes the program code, its current activity, and its resources.

questions.text: Which state does a process enter when it is waiting for an I/O operation to complete?
questions.solution: A process enters the Waiting/Blocked state when it is waiting for an event to occur, such as I/O completion or receiving a signal.

questions.text: What is 'context switching'?
questions.option2: Switching the CPU from one process to another
questions.option4: Swapping data between RAM and hard disk
questions.solution: Context switching is the process of saving the state of a process or thread, so that it can be restored and execution can be resumed from the same point later.

questions.text: Which SQL command is used to retrieve data from a database?
questions.solution: The SELECT statement is used to fetch data from one or more tables in a database.

questions.text: Which keyword is used to sort the result-set of a query?
questions.solution: The ORDER BY keyword is used to sort the result-set in ascending or descending order.

questions.text: What does ACID stand for in DBMS?
questions.solution: ACID is an acronym for Atomicity, Consistency, Isolation, and Durability, a set of properties that guarantee valid transactions.

questions.text: How many layers are in the OSI model?
questions.solution: The OSI (Open Systems Interconnection) model has 7 layers: Physical, Data Link, Network, Transport, Session, Presentation, and Application.

questions.text: Which layer of the OSI model is responsible for routing?
questions.solution: The Network Layer (Layer 3) is responsible for logical addressing and routing of packets across different networks.

questions.text: Which device operates at the Data Link Layer?
questions.solution: A switch operates at the Data Link Layer (Layer 2) to forward frames based on MAC addresses.

questions.text: What is a 'truss' in structural engineering?
questions.option2: A framework of interconnected members forming a rigid structure
questions.solution: A truss is a structural framework composed of members connected at their ends to form a rigid structure, typically triangular units.

questions.text: Which method is commonly used for analyzing forces in truss members?
questions.solution: The Method of Joints is a common technique for determining forces in the members of a truss by analyzing the equilibrium of each joint.

questions.text: For a stable and determinate plane truss, what is the relationship between members (m), joints (j), and reactions (r)?
questions.solution: For a stable and determinate plane truss, the condition is m + r = 2j, where m is the number of members, r is the number of external reactions, and j is the number of joints.

questions.text: What is the 'void ratio' of a soil sample?
questions.option1: Ratio of volume of voids to total volume of soil
questions.option2: Ratio of volume of voids to volume of solids
questions.option3: Ratio of volume of water to volume of voids
questions.option4: Ratio of volume of water to total volume of soil
questions.solution: Void ratio (e) is defined as the ratio of the volume of voids (Vv) to the volume of solids (Vs) in a soil mass (e = Vv / Vs).

questions.text: Which of the following soil types has the highest permeability?
questions.solution: Gravel has the largest particle size and thus the largest voids, leading to the highest permeability among the given options.
